sentences.sentence: The nation The trade offensive against Australia is not really working as Beijing had hoped.

It might be time for the 'don't mention the war' approach.Wilson Edwards, we hardly knew ye.Of all China's cack-handed attempts at media manipulation to shape and shift public opinion, the invention of Swiss biologist Edwards would be a gold medal prospect.Edwards "posted" on his Facebook page that the United States was so "obsessed" with attacking China over the origins of the pandemic, it was intimidating the World Health Organisation and medical researchers.Edwards' comments were amplified by Chinese state media until the Swiss embassy in Beijing did some research and found there was no record of a Wilson Edwards even existing on Switzerland's citizenship register.Perhaps China was hoping to exploit the European nation's neutrality by giving Edwards a Swiss identity, but the embassy publicly called it out as fake news and asked for all references to be stripped from news stories.
Caught in a barefaced lie, China's editors complied.Also this week there was a dummy spit from China over Lithuania allowing Taiwan to open a representative office in Vilnius.

China recalled its ambassador to Lithuania and expelled the Lithuanian envoy from Beijing in retaliation, despite dozens of countries including Australia having similar arrangements.Incidentally, Australia's representative to Taiwan, Jenny Bloomfield, had an audience with Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen on Thursday.Strike three for Chinese diplomacy this week was revelations it had conducted a "massive cyber attack" on Israel, including government agencies and defence bodies, since 2019.According to California cyber security firm FireEye, the Chinese hackers posed as Iranians as they harvested data.

While FireEye did not go as far to directly finger the Chinese government, it noted the hacking group targeted systems that were of "great interest to Beijing's financial, diplomatic, and strategic objectives".While Israel is a US ally, China has invested heavily in its tech sector as well as ports and rail lines as part of the Belt and Road Initiative.
So much so that Israel's seeming ambivalence towards China had prompted US warnings about co-operating too much with Beijing.

The cyber attack revelations provide a handy wake-up call.But the biggest self-inflicted diplomatic blow was two Chinese court rulings.Businessman Michael Spavor, one of two Canadians held by Beijing, was sentenced to 11 years jail for spying, while another court confirmed the death sentence for Canadian drug smuggler Robert Schellenberg.The three are widely viewed as victims of hostage diplomacy in retaliation for Canada's arrest of Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou over fraud charges.
The sentences were announced this week as the legal battle in Canada over Meng's extradition to the US entered its final stages.In comparison, China's wrath against Australia seems on pause for now.

The Chinese embassy in Canberra issued rebukes over Australia's criticism of the Canadian judicial proceedings as well as Marise Payne's call for transparency and humane treatment in the case of Australian journalist Cheng Lei - Friday marked her first anniversary in Chinese custody.Other than a handful of isolated reports, there haven't been any major trade strikes against Australian exporters since late last year.The strategic economic dialogue was suspended, but that was largely symbolic while China in June referred Australia to the World Trade Organisation over tariffs on steel products, in a case that will take eons to resolve.
"It would be hard for Chinese authorities to escape the conclusion that their trade strikes have been ineffective and, indeed, counterproductive.
The Australian economy as a whole has largely been unaffected," says Australia-China Relations Institute head James Laurenceson.
"Meanwhile, the publicity the trade strikes attracted cratered public support for China, and even from groups like the business community.
"While Beijing's daily bombardment may be gone for now, it hasn't been forgotten.
Scott Morrison this week used a speech to the Australian American Leadership Dialogue to propose an annual economic dialogue with the US to tackle economic coercion.And some flashpoints loom.
The government is yet to announce the findings of the Defence Department review into Chinese company Landbridge's lease of Darwin Port.
Similarly, the government will have to decide whether universities can continue to host Confucius Institutes on campus.

Cancelling the lease or the institutes would inevitably invite a strong response from Beijing.Pressure is also mounting on the Morrison government from Coalition MPs for a "diplomatic boycott" of the Winter Olympics that Beijing is hosting next February.Under the push, athletes would still be allowed to attend but Australian government representatives, such as Sports Minister Richard Colbeck, would stay home.

British and US politicians have made similar calls.While Chinese officials boast that a boycott will not succeed, they are very nervous over the Games being used as a platform to humiliate the Communist Party regime over its human rights abuses.On the flip side, attendance by Colbeck or another minister may serve as an icebreaker, given China's refusal to engage with Australian ministers.The Morrison government is sensible to hold fire on any decisions, so it can be part of a co-ordinated approach.Quite rightly, Australia will not give ground on China's 14-point list of grievances, and Payne made clear in a briefing to the Australia China Business Council last week she would not accept any preconditions.But another avenue to reopening dialogue could involve seeking out common ground.
China may be amenable if officials could work up a pre-arranged outcome that ministers can tick off on during a meeting.

Climate change is one topic that readily springs to mind.Call it the "Don't mention the war" approach.Ultimately, though, the $64 million question the Morrison government needs to ask itself is: what's the point of engaging with ministerial counterparts if they are just going to get lip service in return?It hardly seems as if China is making a genuine effort to muzzle the wolf warriors.
Just ask Wilson Edwards.Andrew Tillett is The Australian Financial Review's political correspondent in Canberra.
Laura Tingle is away.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
